sentences.sentence: When the wolf( 狼 ) had eaten, he lay down again in the bed, fell asleep( 睡着了 )  and began to snore( 打鼾 ) very loud.
It happened that a huntsman( 猎人 ) was just passing the house, and thought to himself,
“How the old woman is snoring! I must just see if she wants anything.”
So he went into the room, and when he came to the bed, he saw that the wolf was lying in it.
“Caught you!” he said.
Then just as he was going to fire his gun at the wolf, the thought came to him that the wolf might have eaten the grandmother, and that she might still be saved.
So he did not fire, but took a pair of( 一把 )  scissors, and began to cut open the stomach of the sleeping wolf.
When he had made two cuts, he saw the girl’s little red cap, and then he made two cuts more,
and the little girl jumped out, crying, “Ah, how frightened( 害怕的 ) I have been! How dark it was inside the wolf!”
After that the aged grandmother came out alive also, but scarcely( 几乎不 ) able to breathe( 呼吸 ).
Little Red-Cap, however, quickly fetched( 拿来 ) great stones with which they filled the wolf’s body,
and when he awoke, he wanted to run away, but the stones were so heavy that he fell down at once, and fell dead.
Then all three were delighted( 高兴的 ).
The huntsman took off the wolf’s skin with his knife and went home with it;
the grandmother ate the cake and drank the wine which Little Red-Cap had brought, and got better from her illness,
but Little Red-Cap thought to herself, “As long as( 只要 )  I live, I will never by myself leave the path( 路 ), to run into the wood, when my mother has told me not to.”
Hansel and Grethel
Near a great forest lived a poor woodcutter( 伐木工 ) and his wife, and his two children.
The boy’s name was Hansel and the girl’s Grethel.
They had very little to eat.
A time came when the country’s economy( 经济状况 ) was very poor and the husband could not earn( 赚得 ) anything at all.
As he lay in bed one night thinking of this, and turning and tossing( 翻来覆去 ), he sighed( 叹气 ) heavily, and said to his wife,
“What will happen to us? We cannot feed( 养活 ) our children and ourselves as well.”
“Husband, I will tell you my idea,” answered the wife.
“We will take the children early in the morning into the forest, where it is thickest;
we will make them a fire, and we will give each of them a piece of bread.
Then we will go to our work and leave them alone; they will never find the way home again, and we shall be rid of( 摆脱掉 ) them.”
“No, wife,” said the man, “I cannot do that. I cannot find it in my heart to take my children into the forest and to leave them alone. The wild animals would soon kill and eat them.”
“Oh you fool( 蠢人 )!” said she.
“Do you want all four of us to die of hunger? In that case, you had better( 最好 )  use some of that wood to make our coffins( 棺材 ).” And she gave him no peace until he agreed.
“But I really pity the poor children,” said the man.
The two children had not been able to sleep for hunger, and had heard what their step-mother had said to their father.
Grethel wept( 哭泣 ) bitterly( 伤心地 ), and said to Hansel,
“There is no hope for us.”
“Do be quiet, Grethel,” said Hansel, “and do not worry. I will manage something.”
And when the parents had gone to sleep he got up, put on his little coat, opened the back door, and went out.
The moon was shining brightly, and the small white pebbles( 鹅卵石 ) that lay in front of the house shone like pieces of silver.
Hansel knelt down( 跪下 ), and filled the pockets of his coat as full as he could. Then he went back again, and said to Grethel,
“Don’t worry, little sister, and go to sleep. God will look after us.” and lay down again in his bed.
